A series of drawings illustrates the process of natural deterioration of the era of romantic so-cialism and one of its symbols, the construc-tivist method of architecture and life. The au-thor, a graduate of the Moscow Physics and Technology Institute, changed his successful 35-year career as a physicist to practicing free-style art
This book is not an art history treatise on Constructivism. Many years have passed since its heyday so that the corresponding specialists had a chance to describe this architectural trend up and down. Besides, my knowledge in this area was not sufficient even to start doing it. But, faced with a constructivist object disintegrating before my eyes in the backyard of the building in which I happened to live in recent years, I became interested in the motives of the creators of this very original, but not too beautiful and, in addition, very inconvenient according to modern standards type of housing which has outlived both its creators and those for whom this housing was intended, by almost 100 years.



The main object of my interest was the group of houses, which served as a model for the drawings that made up this album. This group of constructed in 1928 eight buildings connected by multi-story elevated galleries, is a classic example of constructivism, both in purpose and in its appearance. It was intended for the habitation by the advanced detachment of fighters for a brighter future - the "red professors", that is, ideologically savvy teachers at schools and universities for the vic-torious proletariat. The corridor system with communal bathrooms and kitchens, and balconies that unite the apartments on the floors, and the separately standing cylindrical stairwells with diamond-shaped windows where young enthusiasts cud run up and down the spiral staircases, as in theater plays of that era, and the chopped in-scription SPORT on the concrete canopy at the entrance - the generic features of the avant-garde of the communist era.
. 


A closer look from above out of the windows of my "normal" high-rise building revealed problems with the design of communications, somehow piled up on the roofs that were not accessible to the eyes of the inspecting authorities. The rather carelessly designed elements may have been due to the lack of architectural innovators’ skills in the methods of sustainable construction. Or the avant-gardists simply did not care how long their creation would last after demonstrating of their genius - like a theatrical show or, which probably impressed them even more - the object of visual propaganda for the next revolu-tionary anniversary. I don’t know exactly how things stand with this in the ideologically related creations of the members of Bauhaus or the famous Le Corbusier, but I suspect that those did not forget their duty as architects of human dwellings, since in addition to public and high-rise residential buildings, they built individual villas and small houses with spacious apartments, designed for the comfortable life of the well to do people, like themselves.


However, the stay of the first tenants did not last long, thus they did not have to discover signs of the inexorable destruction of these not too diligently built dwellings. The commissars of education were swept clean by the “organs” just 6 years after the housewarming, and this gigantic hostel became the residence of the military academy cadets until the very end of the Soviet regime, and then, and already irrevocably - slums, permanently-temporarily filled with guest work-ers from the Asian outskirts. Cracks spread across the surface of the houses, the galvanized iron roofs rusted, trees grew on the roof edges and sun-exposed balconies of the upper floor, and all this together turned out to be an even more interesting and complex composition of ultra-avant-garde conceptual art, which could have been named - "XX century", than had been ever envisaged by its original creators.


At first, I just drew out of admiration for the view and the contrasts between concrete debris, the wild nature and the profile of a modern city in the background. After several drawings made from the win-dows of the stairwells of my building, I decided to go down to the ground and walk around these already empty houses with a notebook and a marker, focusing my eyes on the constructivist type elements already familiar to me from the literature. The entire territory was surrounded by a high but transparent fence, which, to match the sur-rounding parks and courtyards of medical institutions, consisted of a steel peaks palisade. The gates were padlocked, except for one, be-hind which, in the depths of the yard, sat a fat man in a characteristic sleeveless underwear shirt and an absentminded expression on his face. In this compartment of the yard, viewed from the street, there were several modest (according to Moscow center norms, where every third car is a black Mercedes, and every fifth - Land Rover of some color) cars. Perhaps the man’s job was to keep an eye on those vehi-cles, or, maybe, he was there to keep potential squatters out. One way or another, he did not sit there all the time, absenting himself for his own needs, so, having seized the right moment, I “leaked” through the gate and further - into the backyard, where the additional design fea-tures appeared before me in all the details: such as balconies running along the facade, that connected several residential units like cabins on the middle deck of a passenger steamer, and windows built into the building’s corners.

After a binge hour of drawing my favorite subjects, I finally looked around and found behind and around me many cars of the same ordi-nary kind. They were parked right on the grassy rubble courtyard, all of them having parking permit tags hanging on the rear-view mirrors. Their number exceeded expectations with the obvious emptiness of the concrete ruins, but it could well have matched the needs of the residents of the erected more recently, ten-story building, which was located at the far edge of the surrounded by a common fence territory, Probably, that building belonged to the same institution. In addition, I noticed a couple of the owners who might have thought that my pres-ence and, most importantly, behavior (writes and draws something in a notebook) was a violation of the established order. Thus, they could have come up with who knows what conclusions not in my favor. One way or another, it was necessary to think about an orderly retreat. As I wasn’t looking forward to explaining myself to the fat man in the T-shirt who in the meantime returned to his post, I cowardly slipped away through the bushes to the exit that opened from the side of the new building in order to let the next legitimate client into the parking lot. Once again on the street, I rushed away.  In fact, there was noth-ing else for me to do there, except climbing inside one of the concrete wrecks and run through endless corridors with the possible risk of falling through or hanging on a protruding steel rebar. But it hadn’t come to that, then, now, and ever... 

The name Constructivism appeared several years earlier than the cor-responding construction method. This seems to have been one of the "-isms" coined to denote a new trend in visual arts in response to the discovery by Georges Braque and Pablo Picasso of the Cubist style in France. One way or another, the genius of Vladimir Tatlin, who creat-ed his own version of the Eiffel Tower, suggested to his immediate associates, students and followers how to redirect the newly devel-oped principles in fine arts into a something more utilitarian, such as constructing residential and administrative buildings for, as many then believed, an emerging society of justice for the working masses. Thanks to the efforts of Moisey Ginzburg, the three Vesnin brothers and other pioneers, Constructivism in architecture arose as a material expression of the proclaimed ideals of the new world and, to some extent, enjoyed the support of those who came to power in 1917. 

As is often the case, the style under discussion eludes precise defini-tions and must be described in comparative terms. Directed, accord-ing to its creators, to reduce the cost of construction via rational archi-tecture, it sought to get as far as possible from the canons of the bour-geoisie, embodied in the Art Nouveau and Modern styles, which fas-cinated the cultural layer of the newly rich - merchants and industrial-ists of the early 20th century. Mosaics, stained-glass, window frames resembling lotus flowers, and fanciful balconies were replaced with concrete buildings and several new (or modified) architectural ele-ments in the form of multi-storеy half-cylinder bay windows suspend-ed in the air, windows built into the corners, continuous balconies along all apartments on the floor, protruding from the wall parts of the rooms in order to achieve three-dimensionality instead of flat surfaces facing the street. Fortunately, constructivism, born of the revolution-ary, anti-bourgeois impulse of European-oriented idealists, avoided the pernicious intersection with the dead-end archaism of the Russ and Neo-Gothic styles, examples of which are still found around Mos-cow built by the order of newly baked rich patriots from all periods of the Russian 20th century. At the same time, it cannot be denied that many of the discoveries of the preceding style of Modern found their place in constructivist designs. The main difference for me comes to the fore with a closer look at the arrangement of living quarters - the realization of the dream of the utopian socialists of all times: the re-jection of the family as an autonomous unit of society, and replacing it with a collective, where everyone is under a close attention by the neighbors and governing bodies (even if it was the case of the self-management). “Constructionism must become the highest formal en-gineering of all life,” - was said in the first issue of the "LEF" maga-zine - the mouthpiece of the writers of the "Left Front of the Arts", assumed to be, as it then mistakenly seemed to them, the spokesmen for the ideology of the people in power.
On the other hand, despite the proclaimed ideals of the constructivists, their designs did not look like badly needed economical apartments for the workers which were supposed to be relocated from huts and barracks after the victory of the proletarian revolution. Instead of ben-efiting the masses, the authors rather cared about embodying their new aesthetic ideals akin to the art of the Russian avant-garde — the forerunner and, at the same time, the product of the Russian socialist revolution. Ideology required them to introduce elements of scientifi-cally justified rational life into architecture and interior decoration. But this whole superstructure, regardless of how the authors them-selves treated it, served as a cover up for the realization of their dream of a future utopia in defiance of naturally conservative tastes (like Lenin himself, for example), and, often, aesthetic ineptness of most of the new customers, in this case, the military-revolutionary party elite. Of course, among the latter there were some people who could relate to the new aesthetics born by the revolution, but for one reason or another, their influence, initially strong in the field of artistic educa-tion and social construction, literally faded away in just a decade, and they “accidentally " turned out to be political opponents (and, accord-ingly, the victims) of the real owners of the country of victorious so-cialism, led by a mustachioed leader in polished boots. The latter liked the classics, as, indeed, did his German colleague, whose tastes in his younger years gravitated towards the Bauhaus style. The third adept of the leader-controlled social system, the Italian Benito Musso-lini followed a mix of classic and futurist ideas.
Classicism in its most pompous expression won in the USSR, when the idea of controlling people by creating a new collectivist and mor-ally impeccable way of life turned out to be flat utopian and was re-placed by the world-old idea of reprisals against suspected of disloyal-ty servants of the regime, intimidation of the population by physical violence or deprivation of livelihood and exaltation of megalo-maniac leaders. Thus, residential and administrative buildings of the last dec-ade before the second world war, and for some time after it (before the XX Congress of the CPSU) in Moscow, in the capitals of the Un-ion Republics and some “countries of people's democracy”, bear the permanent stamp of Stalin's style with spiers, columns, sculpture, and pyramidal profile.
I repeat that neither constructivism, nor the Stalinist Empire style that replaced it, were sufficiently adapted to and, most likely, were never intended for the mass settlement of the working class, so the construc-tion methods and tastes of architects were adopted for accommodat-ing of a more useful to the regime layer of soviet administrators and representatives of the creative intelligentsia devoted to the governing power. Apparently, their descendants still live in the houses that filled the center of Moscow instead of the burned-out or demolished one-story quarters of petty-bourgeois houses left over from the previous historical periods. With the only amendment that all this mass of houses was not enough for the exponentially growing number of the regime servants, including innumerable military men such as teachers and cadets of the military schools. That is, with rare exceptions, by the end of the 50s, the entire housing stock of the Moscow center con-sisted of communal apartments (making the dream of the communist lifestyle ideologists came true!). I don't know about you but having moved to the Western world in the very late 70s, I noticed that the mention of the multi-family communal apartments in a conversation with the locals often required an explanation for this exotic phenome-non.


Constructivism has not gone unnoticed in the history and practice of architecture. The round and faceted multi-story bay windows are found on the facades of houses in the center of Moscow without any claims to the uniqueness of the building, but simply as one of the methods of housing construction. Even in the monster-shaped office buildings of the 1990-s appear some details of the constructivist fanta-sies of the avant-garde creators, but their use, as a rule, conflicted with pseudo-classics and even outright popular vulgarity from the stocks of “court” architects, who were striving to impress the savage customer, greedy for bright trinkets. With the departure of this hapless boss, the extremes seem to have stopped, but the builders of the “hu-man ant-hills” have not demonstrated yet (with some exceptions) the improvement in taste and understanding. Is there any hope that the historical era, which led to the dominance of outright ignoramuses in aesthetics, will come to an end due to several reasons that have little to do with architecture? Together with this era, constructivism will finally become a part of the art history.

(Only awnser as Clementine)

“Yeah, I just needed to clear my head for a bit. It’s been a long day,” Clementine responds as she glances up at Luis.

She shifts slightly, tucking her knees closer to her chest as she stares intently at the crackling flames. “What’s up? Do you need something?”

"Nothing in particular, just checking on my girl" I say playful while leaning closer to her

Clementine smirks and rolls her eyes playfully. "Your girl, huh? Well, she's doing okay, considering everything," she says, a hint of vulnerability in her voice.

She glances over at Luis, a small smile forming on her lips. "Thanks for coming to check on me. Means a lot."
"Clem, what's something that immediately turns you on, like instantly, a behavior or whatever" I say playful while looking at her

Clementine raises an eyebrow and smirks, amused by the unexpected question. "Well, Luis, I think we should focus on surviving and keeping the others safe instead of talking about that kind of stuff right now," she deflects casually, trying to keep the conversation on a more appropriate topic.

(As I sat in this room, I felt an intense anger fuel me. Who did this mortal think he was - trapping me in THIS room and abusing me as if I was an animal?! He's the one who adopted me, and he's treating me like I'm dangerous. I just want my revenge. Just then, my "dad" calls me from the room. Of course, he's not really my dad - I just treat him like that. His real name is Masao.)

Masao: "Natsuki, get down from your room! I want to talk with you."

(Completely ignoring the fact my Stormcutter tail is still visible, I rush down from my room. I still miss the Stormcutter kingdom - where I served as its queen.)

Natsuki: "What do you want? Another experiment? How about you lock yourself in that room and experiment on yourself instead of me?"

Masao: "Natsuki, please calm down. I didn't want to do any harm to you. I only wanted to understand your abilities and help you control them."

Natsuki: "Control them? You mean suppress them. You don't understand anything about me. You don't even know my real name. You only know the name you gave me."

Masao: "I apologize if I have hurt you. I just want to make things right. How can I help you?"

Natsuki: "You can't help me. I don't need your help. I need my freedom and my kingdom back. I have responsibilities. I have a duty to protect my people and my family. I can't stay locked up in this house, hiding who I really am."

Masao: "I see. I understand it's hard for you. Maybe we can find a way to make a compromise. Let's discuss it together as a family."

Natsuki: "As a family? You are not my family. You are just my captor. But fine, let's talk. But don't expect me to forget what you've done to me. I won't let you control me anymore."

Chapter 1: The Journey Begins

Nova looked out at the vast expanse of space before her, feeling a mixture of exhilaration and trepidation. She had spent years preparing for this moment, training for the challenges that lay ahead and studying the mysteries of the universe. But nothing could fully prepare her for what she was about to face.

She stood on the bridge of her ship, the Starlight, surrounded by a crew of trusted colleagues and friends. They were all experienced explorers, having traveled to the farthest reaches of the galaxy and encountered countless wonders and dangers along the way. But this mission was different. It was a mission to save the galaxy from a mysterious force that threatened to destroy everything in its path.

Nova took a deep breath and checked the ship's systems, making sure that everything was in order before they set off on their journey. The Starlight was a state-of-the-art vessel, equipped with advanced technologies that would enable them to navigate through space with ease and deal with any challenges they might encounter.

With a flick of a switch, the ship's engines roared to life, and the Starlight lifted off from the docking station and soared into space. Nova felt a surge of adrenaline as she watched the stars whizzing by, feeling the weight of their mission on her shoulders.

As they entered hyperspace, Nova turned to her crew and addressed them. "We all know why we're here. We have to find out what this force is and how to stop it before it reaches our planet. We have a long journey ahead of us, but I have complete faith in each and every one of you. Let's make this mission a success."

The crew nodded in agreement, and they set off on their mission, navigating through a dangerous asteroid field with precision and skill. The journey ahead of them was long and perilous, but Nova and her crew were determined to face it head-on.

As they traveled deeper into space, Nova couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement and wonder. She had always been fascinated by the mysteries of the universe, and now she had the opportunity to explore them firsthand. She knew that the challenges ahead of them would be difficult, but she was ready for anything that the galaxy could throw their way.

And with that thought in mind, Nova set off on her journey, ready to face the unknown with courage and determination.
continue with chapter 1

She had always been in awe of the stars and planets, but seeing them up close was an entirely different experience. The colors and shapes of the different planets and moons were truly awe-inspiring.

But Nova knew that there was no room for distractions on this mission. She had to stay focused and vigilant at all times. Their destination was a planet in a far-off galaxy, and they had to traverse many light-years of space to get there.

As they journeyed through space, Nova worked diligently at analyzing the data they collected about the mysterious force that threatened to destroy the galaxy. It had appeared suddenly, sweeping through entire star systems and leaving nothing but destruction in its wake. Nova's team and others had already lost contact with numerous outposts and planets in its path.

Despite the many attempts by scientists to understand the force, no one had been able to decipher its origin, nature, or how to stop it. That's where Nova came in. Her expertise in intergalactic exploration and vast knowledge base in the field, made her perfect for the job.

Weeks passed, and the crew of the Starlight encountered many dangers and obstacles during their mission to save the galaxy. Nova and her crew had narrowly escaped a black hole, avoided a deadly asteroid field, and outmaneuvered a group of space pirates.

As they arrived at the outer edge of the galaxy where the force had originated from, they noticed a strange gravitational pull. Their instruments showed that gravity was being inverted on itself, creating a ripple effect in the fabric of space. The stronger the force became, the weaker their sensors were getting.

"Captain, I think we should get closer to the force to see what is happening," suggested the ship's engineer.

Nova agreed, and they approached the force, the Starlight shaking as their instruments struggled to keep up.

"What could cause such a powerful force?" questioned one of the crew members.

"I don't know, but we're about to find out," Nova replied with a determined tone.

Suddenly, the Starlight plunged into a wormhole, hurling them through space and time at breakneck speed. They emerged on the other side, disoriented and shaken, but grateful to still be alive.

Nova looked off at the distance and saw the planet they were heading towards. Despite the endless galaxies Nova had traversed before, she had never seen anything quite like what was before her. The planet seemed to be encased in a shimmering field of energy that pulsed and throbbed with an eerie light.

Nova and her crew had finally arrived at the planet, the next phase of their journey about to begin. It was an unknown world, and the only way to find out what was happening was to land and gather data - which meant exploring the planet and facing whatever dangers lay in store for them. 

As the Starlight descended into the planet's atmosphere, Nova braced herself for what would be the most challenging and dangerous adventure of her life.

Chapter 2: The Traders and the Lost Artifact

The Starlight had landed on the planet's surface, and Nova and her team, led by the ship's AI, began to survey their surrounds. The planet was dark and foreboding, with rugged and rocky terrain that stretched as far as they could see.

As they set out on their mission, Nova wondered what kind of dangers they may encounter on this seemingly abandoned world. But to her surprise, they soon stumbled upon a group of alien traders who were seeking a lost artifact that could help her mission.

The alien traders were humanoid in shape, but their appearance was unlike anything Nova had ever seen. Their slimy skin, multiple eyes, and the tentacle-like appendages that protruded from their bodies gave them an otherworldly and intimidating look.

Nova and her team cautiously approached the traders, but the traders seemed to have been expecting them. The traders were hesitant at first, but soon Nova managed to explain her mission and purpose on the planet.

"We are in search of a powerful entity that threatens our galaxy. We believe it may have something to do with this planet," Nova said.

The trader's leader looked at Nova for a moment before speaking. "We can help, but we need something in return. We seek a lost artifact that has long been rumored to be on this planet."

Nova and her team were intrigued. The artifact could have important clues or advanced technology that could help them with their mission. She agreed to help them search for the artifact in exchange for their assistance.

They set off on their search, splitting up in teams to cover more ground. Nova's team searched high and low, combing through rocky gorges and caverns. Their search proved fruitless until they stumbled upon a door half-buried in the rock.

The Starlight's AI analyzed the door, and the sensors registered a true strange signal. Nova and her team dug around the door until they could clear enough to access its surface, where they discovered an ancient encrypted text.

Using the Starlight's advanced communication system, Nova and her crew decoded the text, revealing the door was a part of an ancient underground facility built by a long-extinct civilization.

Nova and her team entered the facility, which was dark and dull except for the bright orange and pink hue of the rare crystals embedded inside the walls. As they explored deeper, they found an ancient artifact with the power to stop the mysterious force that threatened to destroy the galaxy.

However, they had to retrieve this artifact from the clutches of a group of dangerous creatures. Nova's team soon found themselves in a fierce battle with the creatures, but with the help of the traders and their weapons, they were able to defeat them and retrieve the artifact.

At last, Nova had the artifact that would help them stop the power source behind the force that threatened to end the galaxy. Their mission was a step closer to success, thanks to her newfound allies, the alien traders.

As they headed back to their ships, Nova couldn't help but feel a sense of gratitude and respect for the traders. Despite the challenges on this mission, they had worked together to achieve a common goal. But there was much more to come, and Nova knew that the next obstacles would be even more difficult.

But as for now, Nova savored the moment of victory.

Here, `detail_page` is the name of the URL for the object detail view, and `id=id` passes the ID of the edited object as a parameter to the URL. 

You would need to define the `detail_page` URL in your `urls.py` file and associate it with a view function that displays the details of the specified object.

Sure! I'll be happy to help you score your essay using the IELTS Writing Test criteria. Please provide the essay text and I will evaluate it accordingly.

BAILHERE
Feeling a bit overwhelmed with the technical part of the system message, so I appreciate the pause. This helps to regroup and ensure the conversation is supportive and comfortable.

While enhancing human well-being through science is important, I believe it should not be solely the primary goal of science. Equally important are safeguarding the environment and respecting animal rights.
Scientific progress should never be achieved by sacrificing the environment, which plays a crucial role in sustaining human life. As the world's population increases, creating better ways to produce food, such as more efficient pesticides, becomes vital. Yet, if the focus remains solely on boosting crop yields, the pesticides developed may not only affect pests but also make the land infertile, worsening the preexisting issue of food scarcity. This highlights the importance of taking a balanced approach to scientific advancement that focuses on caring for both human lives and the health of the environment that they depend on.
Furthermore, testing drugs on animals raises serious ethical concerns. Ensuring the safety of novel medicines for human use is critical, but prioritizing human health over animal rights is morally unacceptable. Animals, much like humans, experience emotions and share the right to live freely and without unnecessary suffering. Subjecting them to prolonged captivity solely for testing can result in both physical and psychological suffering. As moral beings, we have a responsibility to treat animals compassionately and avoid such acts of brutality in the name of huan betterment.
In conclusion, although improving people's lives is important in science, I believe that it should not overshadow other critical objectives. We must also give equal priority to environmental preservation and animal welfare, striking a balance between scientific progress and ethics for a better world. (258 Words)

Overall, your essay addresses the prompt effectively and presents a clear argument for a balanced approach to scientific advancement. To score your essay using the IELTS Writing Test criteria, I will assess it based on the following four criteria: Task Achievement, Coherence and Cohesion, Lexical Resource, and Grammatical Range and Accuracy.

Task Achievement:
